Introduction.Definition: CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) is a stylesheet language used to describe the presentation of a web page, including colors, layout, and fonts.
Introduction.History: CSS was first introduced by HÃ¥kon Wium Lie in 1996 to separate content from design in web development.
Features: Separation of content and style: Keeps HTML structure clean.
Reusability: Styles can be reused across multiple pages.
Responsive design: Helps create flexible and adaptive layouts.
Animations and transitions: Enables interactive and dynamic effects.

HowItWorks.WorkingMechanism: CSS works by selecting HTML elements and applying styles to them using selectors and properties.
WaysToApply: Inline CSS: Applied directly to an HTML element using the style attribute.
Internal CSS: Written inside a <style> tag within the HTML document.
External CSS: Stored in a separate .css file and linked using the <link> tag.

Usage.WhyUseIt: CSS enhances the appearance of web pages, ensures consistency, and improves user experience.
HowItIsUsed: Styling text: Changing fonts, colors, and sizes.
Layout design: Creating grids, flexbox, and responsive designs.
Animations: Adding transitions, keyframes, and hover effects.
Themes and Skins: Customizing appearance dynamically.

Selectors.Definition: Selectors are patterns used to target HTML elements and apply styles.

BoxModel.Definition: The CSS box model consists of margins, borders, padding, and the content area of an element.
BoxModel.Example: div { margin: 10px; padding: 5px; border: 2px solid black; }

Positioning.Definition: Positioning controls how elements are placed in the layout.

Flexbox.Definition: Flexbox is a layout model that allows elements to align and distribute space efficiently in a container.

Grid.Definition: CSS Grid is a powerful layout system for designing web pages in a grid-based manner.
